Thomas L Roche wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger Sun May 2, 2004 7:37 pm (rearranged)
<snip />

>  > Separation is, however, a majority of the solution. It is easily 80%
>  > of the solution, if not more.
> 
> False. You are claiming that a properly designed UI need not be fully
> tested. This is

Rudeness objection. Dial it down a notch, will you?

> * merely speculative: for all your design, if you haven't tested, you
>   don't know that it works. (I might add that the vast majority of
>   customers care much more that the code they've bought works as
>   specified than that it is well designed.)

Please lecture someone else about things they already know.

<snip />
> I will go so far as to claim, ceteris paribus, better one's code be
> thoroughly tested (presuming it passes those tests :-) than well
> designed. (I will also claim that thorough testing promotes good
> design, but that's because I'm a TDD true believer.)

Agreed, however, when I don't know what to do, I minimize the amount of 
untested code, which is what a thin GUI is all about. I don't think you 
can argue that this is a bad practice. One has to start somewhere.

Now it turns out that the mere act of minimizing the amount of untested 
code introduces other improvements in the design. This has been my 
experience, and I'm quite happy with it. This motivates me to continue 
to use this approach, even though the original motivation for it no 
longer exists.

Of course, now that I have confidence in my ability to test web page 
templates in isolation -- something I didn't have in the past -- I test 
them. Did you miss that part of what I'd written?

I'd appreciate it if you'd lecture less and discuss more. Perhaps I am 
just being a bit sensitive, but I find your approach a little brusque, 
bordering on rude.

Take care.
-- 
J. B. Rainsberger,
